Award.AbstractNarration: This EAGER project under the direction of PI Gary Holton takes advantage of a unique opportunity to assess the feasibility of documenting indigenous astronomy in Alaska and Canada. Although astronomy is a fundamental component of all Alaska Native cultures, there has so far been no systematic effort to document indigenous knowledge of the Alaskan sky. Rapid change in traditional land use has led to this astronomical knowledge being even more endangered than the indigenous languages themselves. In this pilot project we focus on Gwich?in, the most viable of Alaska?s Dene (Athabaskan) languages. Extrapolating on more than a year of archival research, the project will work with culture bearers in the Alaska Gwich?in region to document Gwich?in terminology for starts, constellations, and astronomical events. The project will coordinate closely with work in progress with Canadian Gwich?in being conducted under the auspices of the Gwich?in Social and Cultural Institute. Finally, the project will seek to corroborate the existence of several major cosmological themes, which permeate Northern Dene languages. The primary project deliverable will be a report describing Gwich?in knowledge of the sky, along with star charts localized to the Gwich?in region. These materials will be made available through the Alaska Native Language Archive to be used by both scholars and educators. In addition to linguist Holton, project participants include Leslie McCarthy, Curator of Oral History at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, and Chris Cannon, graduate student and astronomy educator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to assess the feasibility of documenting Gwich’in knowledge of the sky. Gwich’in is a Dene (Athabascan) language spoken in Alaska and Canada. The language is critically endangered. That is, it is no longer being learned by children in most of the Gwich’in region. As knowledge of the language fades, so too does knowledge of highly specialized domains of knowledge, including astronomy. Previous researchers have suggested that the Gwich’in and other Dene language groups have very limited knowledge of the sky. Indeed, prior to our study only a few Gwich’in terms for stars and constellations had been recorded, including the term Yahdii, usually translated as Big Dipper. However, our initial archival investigation suggested that the equation of Yahdii with Big Dipper may not be entirely correct. And it is this clue which motivated our research.

 Working with traditional knowledge experts in the Gwich’in region of Alaska we were able to confirm that Yahdii is actually a whole-sky constellation spanning a huge swath of night sky. It is indeed based around the Western Constellation known as the Big Dipper, but it is much larger than that. The Gwich’in constellation Yahdii is envisioned as a tailed man crouching above the sky, and the stars forming the various parts of this tailed man are identified in the Gwich’in language using body parts. Thus, the stars which form the Big Dipper are literally ‘Yahdii’s tail’ (identified as “A” in the attached image). Other parts of Yahdii are identified as hands, legs, feet, ears, eyes, snout, head, etc.

 From the viewpoint of Gwich’in country, located north of the Arctic Circle, Yahdii is a circumpolar constellation. That is, the entire figure appears to rotate above during the arctic night. This allows the constellation to be used for telling time and navigating across the land. For the Gwich’in, a quick glance up at the sky reveals the orientation of Yahdii and hence confirms time and direction.

Half a century ago the anthropologist Robert McKennan wrote that the Gwich’in “... had never been much interested in the heavenly bodies, and this is borne out by the paucity of starlore...” (The Chandalar Kutchin, 1965, p. 73). We attribute our strikingly different conclusion to the fact that we had the opportunity to work closely with Gwich’in speaking collaborators, to travel with them during the arctic winter, and to observe the night sky first-hand. Seeing the sky through the eyes of a Gwich’in expert reveals a very different view of the stars, one that is not influenced by constellations handed down from the the ancient Babylonians. In this way we begin to see a unique arctic view of the sky, embedded in the Gwich’in language.

Our preliminary research with speakers of neighboring Dene languages suggests that the concept of a whole-sky constellation like Yahdii may not be limited to Gwich’in. Even the distant Southern Dene of the US Desert Southwest make use of body-part terminology to indicate stars within larger constellations. The documentation of cultural astronomy among the Gwich’in and related groups remains an important area for future research
